p: Tuberculosis (TB) is a bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium Tuberculosis. This bacteria has caused more deaths than any other infectious pathogen, although treatment and prevention methods exist [ 65]. Out of an estimated 1.7 billion individuals who are currently infected with M. tuberculosis, 5–10% will develop active TB and will transmit the bacteria to 10 to 15 individuals each year [ 66]. Therefore, a vaccine against TB has been, and still remains, essential to contain this infectious disease. Today, the only licensed TB vaccine available is the Bacille Calmette–Guérin (BCG) LAV [ 67].
